title: Round II: Nightscout Dexcom-Moto G case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This case holds a Moto G phone, the Dexcom G4 reciever and the TTVJ Micro USB to Micro USB cable together. It protects the Dexcom port very well, and its easy to snap off the phone for charging. We made sure the Dexcom doesn't block the phones camera. You can purchase the cable here bit.ly/19uLplH. It only works with this cable, we chose it because of its length and quality. Remember, the red end goes to the phone. The file is available for download so if you have access to a 3d printer you can print it and modify. We would love to see what you do with it. If you dont have access to a 3d printer you can just purchase it from Shapeways: https://www.shapeways.com/shops/Rounds. The quality and material will be perfect.
How to assemble: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LnTJ9gSJb2g
Please give feedback, and would love to see pictures of your device on the CGM in the Cloud Facebook group. Aloha. The Rounds Crew. Mads, Sara and Ian. http://rounds.linehq.com.

author: camini

description.text: This thing allows you to use shorter smooth rods (70cm by default) for the build of your 3DR Simple 3D printer, significantly reducing the cost. As an added bonus, it should make the frame stiffer, too.

Attach the extender (which prints upside-down) to the top of the bottom motor mount part. Glue is recommended. Use M4 T-Slot bolts to secure the extender to the extrusion.  
If you use the STLs, you can reduce your short-rod length by 70cm and retain your target build height. Or you can use these extenders and increase your build height by 70cm (assuming your t-slot extrusions are long enough).

A ceramic hamster was scanned using DAVID laser scanner (focusable line laser and Logitech webcam pro).  Resulting large mesh was decimated using Meshlab.  I added a flat bottom using Blender. Paws in smaller figure have a sharp overhang, which I tried to \'fix\' in Blender (large figure).  But, the curled paws look so much cuter... so that\'s the version I posted here.  I also fixed the eyes on the large figure - they were not very visible in the decimated scan.
Both samples printed with Ultimachine white PLA, using Repsnapper.  The settings need a lot of work ....
Print.  Say, 'Awwww, isn't it cute!"  Play with it or give it away.  Have fun!

Another balloon car. Loosely modelled on a Bugatti Type 35 first made in 1924 which won over 1,000 races. After 35 versions it last rolled off the production line in 1931. The T35 was the only automobile of its time that could be driven both on the road and in races.
For the tech heads:
Engine 8-cylinder in-line engine, 3 valve/cylinder, overhead camshafts
Cubic capacity/bore [cmÂ³/mm] 199/60 x 88
Carburetor 2 Solex
Power [HP at revolutions/min] 90 at 5500
Forward gears 4
Tire size 710 x 90
Weight [kilograms] approx. 750

There are 4 STL files. 3 are for printing. The assemble.stl is the completed print just for reference. I have replaced the original body with a solid body.
The body is scaled to 90% of max size of Replicator 2. If it was scaled down a bit so you could print all the parts in one go. The only reason the wheels and hubs are printed seperately are because I wanted them in different colours.
The hubs are a press fit onto the end of the axles. I used a dab of polystyrene cement to fix them semi-permanently. The wheels and hubs will require a bit of a ream to fit.
I am printing this as we speak. If any problems I will update.
BTW> made in 3dsMax. if anyone wants the model in any other file format I will be happy to provide.

author: rhuff

title: 3DRAG/K8200 Z axis cable driven parallel drive system

description.text: This mod ensures the Z axis is driven from both ends, using a closed loop cable drive system, The cable used is a steel cored fishing line, that should be able to hold 41 KG's, though several strands could probably be used at once.

I am leaving this as a work in progress, because there are several things that I think could be improved. Additional parts needed are the above mentioned fishing line or an equivalent cable, 6 x 608 bearings, 8 x M5x25 bolts (I found ones with hex heads, but normal bolts should work just as well) 8 M5 washers and nuts (I had 6 square M5 nuts left from the original kit, those are preferred, but normal M5 nuts will slide in the slotted extrusion just fine), and 4 zip ties. The fishing line comes with crimp-on sleeves, other cables might need a different method to make eyelets at their ends.
The bearings are a tight press fit in the pulleys, I used a small bench vise to press them in, and another bearing as a spacer to get the last half mm in. Each pulley is sandwiched between a "cap" and a "stand", and bolted through both and a support to the frame
In order to slide on the two nuts that support the large pulleys at the bottom of the loop I loosened the bolts holding the vertical frame, and levered it slightly up so that a nut could be inserted at either side. After bolting that back, I loosened the bolts holding the upper cross member of the frame so that I could lift it until the extrusion was clear enough to slide another 4 nuts on it. Finally, to work on the Z axis, I loosened the bolt holding it to the carriage and those of the bearing block on the right, lifted it clear of the z carriage, rotated it a bit and pulled it free of the right block. At this point the right smooth rod can be easily disassembled to replace the linear bearing holder. The linear bearing holder is derived from a part of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:396981, which is GPL, which is the reason why this licence was adopted. If necessary I can re-release the other parts under a creative commons licence.

comments.text: Very nice!  This is much more elegant that the dual z-axis system I put together.  A dual leadscrew setup needs two follower nuts which adds a bunch of drag that stalls the motor sometimes.  Your setup is just simple and clean.  I am quite tempted to convert my rig to this system.
comments.author: crashmatt

comments.text: Actually, I don't like the zip ties very much, but they are a quick and simple solution. Another problem with this arrangement is that the cable will sit in the groove of the pulley nearly static for a long time, and I fear this will eventually cause the pulley to deform. I can't see a solution to this for the large pulley, but maybe the small ones could be reduced to simple caps leaving the cable to ride directly on the bearing surface. Finally, the entire thing can be assembled without losing any print volume, but the space is tight. there's the risk of losing 10mm of build volume in X if the large pulleys are not in the exact position. I have since printed a few other things with this mod fitted and it seems to work fine so far. Personally i think the double threaded rod approach is better, if you experience binding then probably there's some misalignment rather than just the nut friction. However, I think that the main advantage of my approach is that the parts are easy to find. And compared to dual motor Z axis machines you can still adjust the position of  by hand.
comments.author: crashmatt

Dual extruder mount for the ordbot hadron.
The uploaded stl files uses M4 bolts to screw it down to the carrige, the ordbot comes with holes for M3 so either you need to drill out the holes or change in the open scad file to use M3 bolts instead.
The nema 17 motors have a depth of 40 mm. If you want to use other motors it is possible to configure this in the scad file.
Made to be used together with a minimalistic direct drive extruder solution like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15718.
Update: Solution to mount cooling fans can be found here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:471515

Will be uploading firmware upgrades in about another 3 weeks or so ( bear with me because im not the greatest C++ coder for i've only been working in C++ for about 2 years, plus i'm just getting used to the firmware =(..). Also if anyone wants other files (including source firmware files in a little bit) can be uploaded in a couple of days. Also still making the printable derlin pieces. They will be up by thursday morning, Nov 4th, 2010.

Once i get the other hot end for the other extruder i will put the ending of the extruder together. FIRST: Print out these parts listed below (maybe tricky on a makerbot (working on a makerbot friendly version)) Print out Plate A.stl then Plate BD.stl twice for that is plate B and D (kinda obvious but why not say)
TWO: drill the holes out a little bit to ensure the holes are big enough for the m3 screws.
THREE: Put all plastic parts together. Just like with your old mk4/5 except with plastic plates not acrylic.
-Plate A is first to be put down, then B on top of A, then the derlin pieces will go on(stated above that will be posted later), and finally Plate D goes on. Will have pictures and wayy better instructions by thursday,

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

title: All laser cut Mendelmax wood Assembly Hardware.  5mm birch plywood for model 1.5.  Additional design features for easy lasering and added structural strength.

description.text:
10/09/2014 - Taking longer than I thought. I've done a lot of tests and trials and keep coming up with new ideas. Made many changes and additions and uploaded some new photos. Also uploaded the latest source file along with a pdf vesion. I have left to finish the design for the x motor and idler wheel. Also need to make a controller dock and limit stops. Plan to have 100% all lasered wood/acrylic 3D printer in the end, no 3D printed parts.
.
After having the Mendel Prusa model for over a year and tired of tweaking it, I decided to upgrade to the Mendelmax, v1.5. I'm making all of the support hardware from 5mm birch plywood with a laser. I started from this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:166838.
.
After cutting this design and trying it out, I came up with a lot of enhancements. I have made some additions too. Upgrading many of the mechanical parts to higher quality and precision.
.
Making changes specifically for easy laser work. Reworked the x-ends to cut out a hex to hold the nuts for the 2 z-threaded rods.
Adding structural support in several areas.
.
I've done a lot of design, retrofit and rework. This is a work in progress, so keep checking back, hope to be complete is about a week or so.
5mm birch plywood.  All cut from laser.  Glue and 10-32 1 inch bolts with washers and nuts needed.

comments.text: I have a MendelMax 1.5.  Conventional build.  Building a Tantilot as I have a need for a portable unit.  I just enjoy building things.  I have a laser cutter, cnc router, small milling maching.  I LOVE to build.

title: Parametric Inverted Y Motor Mount for MendelMax
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement Y motor mount for Mendel Max printers, although it could be modified to work with other aluminum extrusion frame printers. Advantages over stock part:

  • Full 4 hole mounting for strength

  • Motor can be mounted with thermal tape or thermal grease contacting aluminum extrusion to act as heat sink. (note thermal grease in 4th image above)

  • Inverted nature puts compressive stress on support elements rather than stress which acts on delaminating layers.

  • Fully parametric with OpenSCAD source provided

  • I like curved supports

• print (I would not recommend PLA for motor mounts since motors can get quite warm and PLA gets soft)

  • use 4 m3 screws to mount motor (motor goes on opposite side from curved supports so that the belt travels between the m5 mounting pads)

  • put thermal tape or grease on motor side to contact aluminum extrusions (note thermal grease in 4th image above).

  • mount assembly to extrusions with m5 screws

  • adjust belt tension as necessary since motor is closer to extrusion
    • OpenSCAD editing:
    This uses configuration.scad.dist and functions.scad from Prusa's i3 project. These must be in the same folder as YMotorMnt_INV.scad. These files are found here:
    https://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3.

comments.text: Works great! I made mine with PLA, no issues yet but then my stepper is barely warm to the touch.

remixed_from.title: Eric's Wade's Collaborative Dual Feed Extruder

title: direct i3 carriage collaborative wade remix

description.text:
version of collaborative wade fused with i3 carriage.
i've found i3 carriage+adapter+collaborative wade having too many points of freedom. so fused i3 carriage with wade, skipping the adapter . as side fx wade got rotated so (in theory) there should be a bit more room for second extruder.
this design is printable, but is not extensively tested yet.
it should be sturdier, and it has just three bolts to unscrew in case of carriage switch anyway so even less hassle to take it down than with classic option. there are two versions, one is with extruder located at bottom beam - it is extra sturdy but at cost of reduced print space in Z,
and version with extruder located at the top beam - it is more flexible and there is problem with heat routing (there are some vent holes but some of the heat goes into motor area, while rest on the back of carriage - both not very fortunate places). EDIT : added
i3carriage fuse_higher_beam_offset_better_x_ca... files , this is 8mm rods version with better carriage. p.s. all carriage designs are not mine , but i've forgot where i've got them from and can't find them again - please forgive me. i'll be happy if anyone will point me whom i should credit.
i think 10mm version is just stock i3 rework design...

comments.text: I have updated the body STL file.  I had noticed that you can get some false positive extruder jam errors because the filament can move over away from the encoder wheel.  And if this happens the encoder wheel will not turn and thus giving you a false jam error.  The new body now fits inside of the extruder opening (not around it)  On some printers you may need to run a drill bit in the hole to make sure your filament moves through it smoothly.

This is a wall mount for a ¼" acrylic artwork made for me. There was no good way to attach the acrylic to the wall, so I decided to create and 3D print a solution. The acrylic sits in the mount which must first be attached to your wall. In my case, it was attached to a brick wall. You must also drill holes in the flat back plate of the piece to attach to your wall. I did not include drill holes in the piece because everybody's wall is different, and they may want to adjust those.

The wall mount was made for a specific work of art given to me by a friend. The work of art is on a piece of ¼" acrylic. We had a hard time hanging the work of art, so I created a wall mounted 'seat' for it. You will need to mount the bracket by drilling holes in the flat back plate, and then attach that to your wall. The ¼" acrylic should sit in the wall mount. You may have to attach a piece of 3m double sided tape to the top of your work of art to hold it in place. This was a pretty specific project, so not sure if anybody else out there can use it, would love to see somebody find a need for it!

My new gimbal didn't quite clear the ground even using the tall landing gear (no, it's not a GB200 - I can't see paying $200 for a gimbal that doesn't offer pitch control). This is a simple elevator skid with through holes for zip ties to attach it to the landing gear. It adds about ½" of height to the gear and <10 grams each.

This is about as easy a print as you'll get. Works fine at 400 microns with 10% infill. In fact, less infill (for less weight) is better, as it has almost no need for strength.  
Print one for each landing strut, and place it with the hole close to the end under the "notch" in the landing skid. Zip-tie it through the holes using that notch to secure one zip-tie, and behind the struts for the other.

Zip tie saddle for mounting wires and stuff. I needed a bunch of these for a project and they're ridiculously priced at the hardware store (like $5 for 10 saddles), so I figured I would just print some out.
Supports zip ties with a pass-through dimension of 5mm x 2mm (basically a standard sized zip tie)

I printed this out on my Ultimaker with 100% infill, 100mm/sec feed rate, and .1mm layer height. I also had retraction turned on for spans >= 2mm. If you print it as is, it will need to make a bridge of 5mm, so keep that in mind- it should be pretty easy so long as you don't print too hot.
This saddle is designed to use double sided mounting tape (the white foam kind with green checker backing). I printed mine with PLA and with a pretty tight zip tie it seemed pretty solid. If you're going to hang anything heavier duty on it, maybe consider printing in ABS or Nylon.
This part could easily be remixed to have a countersunk screw hole- if anybody would find something like that useful let me know and I'll put one up.

title: Aquaponics - Spray Nozzle Fixture
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A spray nozzle for the Japan Aquaponics Micro System.
The nozzle broadens the grow bed siphon water outflow and directs it to stimulate water movement in the fish tank so that debris are pushed towards the pump. Debris are sucked up by the pump and returned to the grow bed so that the bacteria can break them down into nitrates and nitrites to fertilize the plants.
The design intent was to passively create the desired water flow in the fish tank, reducing the need for maintenance.

Slice and print.
The nozzle has been successfully printed in PLA with 100 micron layers.

description.text: This is a simpler replication of the Nescafe Dolce Gusto coffee pod holder.  At the time of making there was a 3 month waiting period to purchase, so I thought I would make our own in the mean time.

• Created for Makerbot Replictor 2;
  • Using Black PLA, Temp of 220 degrees C, speed set at 60 mm/s (seem to be the best combination);
  • The STL has been run through NetFabb;
  • To create a similar size to the Nescafe version, scale the STL file by 150%. You may be able to stretch it to 175% in the Replicator 2;
  • No supports are required to print, even though there is a 1mm edge on the bottom, Replicator 2 seems to handle to without any problems;
  • Base and top have been sized so you print and superglue each new level (hence the 1mm edge)

A cruiser is the class of ship between a destroyer and a battle ship. Large enough to count as the mainstay of a more backwater system these ship pack a punch as well as have enough armor to hold out in the center of battle.
(Not sure why the thing view has it pointed up, its not supposed to be.)
Just a thing I decided to make in Inventor 2014. Thought it was cool enough to upload here. Its not incredibly complex but the individual turrets on it are quite small. If you blow it up to a large size it should be fine. If you print this you will probably need supports on it.
Got the idea from http://infinite-auran.deviantart.com/art/Missile-Cruiser-Front-View-182644832
Its a pretty close copy, just not intended for the same use (If space combat was a thing) Just wanted to see what I could make from the example. EDIT: just added it cut in half, should be able to print it with supports with relative ease.

title: Watch Links with 1.75mm Filament pins.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Saw a friend with a neat metal link watch and was inspired to try my hand at a printed variant. I measured my watch strap to be ~24mm but pretty much free-handed the rest of it.
I ultimately ended up with a link 24mm W x 14.5mm L x 5mm D, and 9.5mm axle to axle on center. FYI, this is just the link. Haven't designed a clasp/buckle yet. Included both the Rhino5 model and a ready-to-print STL
Just print out as many links as you like, then line them up and push a length of filament through the holes. Trim the filament and repeat for as many link pairs as you have.

Two 3 1/4" lengths of 1" PVC pipe
Two 4" lengths of 1" PVC pipe
One 7" length of 1" PVC pipe.
Purchase four elbow connectors for 1" PVC pipe (~30cents each)
Connect it all together as shown in the picture for a simple filament spool holder for your Printrbot Simple

description.text:
A remix of LIPS handcuff key by CookieMonster with a steampunk twist. It's meant to hang from a necklace and is hopefully harder to spot as handcuff keys.
A friend of mine wanted the key to hang off a necklace. This thing was made with Tinkercad.

Building on the Makerwatch SSG that I published a while back, I wanted to create a solution for people building Arduino prototypes, so they didn\'t have to resort to beige boxes. This skeletal piece allows users to create flexible SSG cases for their arduino projects by clipping on skeletal supports, and covering the skeleton with a skin. In fact, this skeletal piece can work with any circuitboard, though minor adjustments to the mesh must be made, depending on the width of the board. The compared to an injection molded housing, this system is much cheaper to make in small runs (especially if users make their own skins). Additionally, the system can be adapted to a variety of configurations modular board chunks -- as you can see, there is a transparent area of skin covering a touch screen. The screen works, as demonstrated in this explanation video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3JtB_P1oORI The SSG design framework, developed by Dominic(me) at the Humblefactory, breaks an object down into different functional layers -- skin, skeleton, and guts. The exciting thing about this separation is how it makes the process of making derivative objects, or entirely new remixes much easier. All you need to know to make a new SSG object is how to sew, and where to buy some fly fabric. The skin gives most of the style, and some of the function (clasps, pockets, pen-loops -- you decide!) I will be updating this description as I complete more tests to the design. Stay tuned, and in the mean time, give it a test yourself!! You can find all the components linked below, or roll your own with boards and shields you have laying around. I\'m particularly interested to hear what sort of sensing you might do with a \"Tricorder\" -- chime in in the comments, or send me an email @ The Humblefactory.

One pair of skeleton clips will cover either the Arduino Uno (formerly the DM) http://arduino.cc/ or the Mega http://arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoardMega2560 . The skin for this could be as simple as a sewn hemmed tube out of a semi-stretchy material (knit polyester, or wool felt work well. I suppose you could even use shrink film for a more permanent solution) These boards can accept multiple types of shields, or daughter boards. Limor sells some great shields at Adafruit:
http://www.adafruit.com/index.php?main_page=index&cPath=17_21 and the Liquidware shields I used for the touchscreen can be found here:
http://www.liquidware.com/shop/show/PMP/Portable+MegaPalm A search for \"Arduino Shield\" will return more hits than you could ever use. Please refer to the instructions for the Makerwatch SSG for more detailed information on dealing with SSG systems: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3815

remixed_from.title: Quick-Fit X carriage and Extruder - LM8UU

description.text:
So i backed the kickstarter for QUBD's dual extruder, and it arrives to much excitement only to find out that it is too short to mount on my Quick fit X carriage!  So after hearing nothing from their tech support people about mounting it on a Prusa Mendel, I get to work designing my own mount.  I designed a bowden connection to mount both hotends on a single alumium block, limiting the amount of build volume lost by the two heads, and combined that with a quick-fit plate for richrap's quickfit extruder.  
I use the poor man's 1.75mm bowden fittings of an M4 nut on 4mm teflon tubing, so that is what this is designed for.  When testing is complete I'll publish updated stl and design files.

Print.
Install bowden tube.
use two qubd extruders on a quick fit carriage.

title: Cam idler pusher for V5 micro extruder.

description.text:
well i wanted to add spring tensioners to my V5 so i went ahead and added a cam tensioner. Here it is... i am using M4 bolts as spacers to get the springs loaded properly.
UPDATE: 2/3/13
Added a stl for the body with out the follower inside, and one for the follower by it self, plus i uploaded a plate with all 3 pieces (with the cam follower printed out side the body) the carriage still needs a bit of work before i release it the fan mounting holes are 2mm to close....

step 1 print the body( i printed 3 shells 50% infill... but thats most likely more then it needs)
let it cool down on the bed, I warped my first try pulling it too early.
Step 2 print the level. a M4 bolt acts as the bearing surface for the cam lever assemble paying attention to lever position by flipping it it will actuate the opposite direction. so you can make it lock either pulling twards you or pushing away.
do not remove the support material in the middle of the housing it becomes the cam follower that pushes on the idler it will break free the first time you lock it down. install will longer M3 bolts not sure how long mine are and its printing right now!!!
adjust the M3 bolts to get the tension right so that you fully engage the lever when it is "on" the lever may not stay in the mid position if you dont set the tension with the lever fulling engaged.
UPDATE 2/3/13
Sounds like M3 50mm cap screws are about the proper length for the idler it will depend on the springs you use of course.

comments.text: ok modified parts are up.
comments.author: xochal

comments.text: originally the bearing bosses in the body where wider I thought they would need support.  so it was just a support piece.  Eventually i figured out i was going to have to use a cam follower so i just solidified the support material.  i will upload a new stl with the cam follower printed separately and nothing in the body cavity.  thank you for the feed back!
comments.author: xochal

comments.text:
Russ -
My cam follower didn't pop off. It needed some exacto work. Would it make sense to have the cam follower printed with the idler? FYI, I used M3x50s.

An easy-to-make laptop stand to allow adequate cooling.

• Print two copies of the .stl file. These make the two sides of the stand.

  • Get some 1/4 inch aluminum rod from your nearest Home Depot, Lowe's or real hardware store. Cut the rod into three 8 inch sections and thread each side of each piece using a tap-and-die set.

  • Put 1/4 inch nuts on the each side of each rod, attach the printed sides and cap with 1/4 inch acorn nuts.

Please note, i quickly made the instructions, so if I forgot anything, or if you dont understand, please comment and i will fix it.
Print out.
Glue to thicker material.
Cut out and fold where needed
Glue the parts together.
use paperclip as an axle.
Finish the glueing and use a string of some kind and put it into the hole.
Pull it and it would be a crude yet working gyroscope.
This is a work in progress, so it will change over time once i get pictures of it working,my camera broke so it would take a while to fix it.

author: dombeef

title: Servo Horns For the Towel RC Plane

description.text: This is a servo horn for the towel RC airplane.  Although this is not needed to build the plane, I think this is a nice addition to the towels I have built.

Print the servo horns and build a towel RC airplane. You can get the plans for the towel from http://brooklynaerodrome.com/ or Make Magazine's web site at http://makeprojects.com/Project/%22The+Towel%22+R-C+Stunt+Plane/2042/1#.UQ3sUn0Vlko These servo horns can be mounted on the elevons with double sided tape and zip ties. I tend to use the hole that is furthest forward, but you can try different holes to adjust the position of the elevons when the controls are centered. Since the plane does not have shaped airfoils for wings, you fly at a bit higher angle of attack for level flight. I printed this on my Ultimaker using normal settings in Cura. I used a heated bed at 70 degrees C. We built 4 towels today and the servo horns worked great. I am not associated with Brooklyn Aerodrome in any way, but I am grateful for their work on the towel and enjoyed talking to them at the Maker Faire last year.

comments.text: Hey, it's Andrew (the Education Director) from Brooklyn Aerodrome, I just printed a set of these, and Breck and I are going to try them out tomorrow night.
comments.author: bridge2nowhere

title: Dux Centre Flush Toilet Cistern  - Bezel surrounding flush buttons in lid (parameterised)

description.text:
This bezel goes around the twin flush buttons in the lid of the cistern. Somehow it can be flushed down the toilet if you are saddled with a sufficiently talented family http://www.dux.co.nz/bathroom/dux-cisterns-and-pan-pacs printed in ABS, 6.7g . Used 0.25mm layers, as the curved top is very poor otherwise
A dab of silicon rubber or holtmelt glue will stop it falling out like the original one did

printed in ABS, 6.7g .
Used 0.25mm layers, as the gently curved top is very poor otherwise. Found it is best (for easy of removing support) to print upside down, and break off the support by pressing it way at the inside, rather than from the outside. However if you want a clean melted top surface then print it the right way up. You might want to change
LidT=2.7+0.2; //thickness of plastic Lid
to suit, as the given value is tight on my printer

Dual Z axis rod mod for MendelMax 1.5
Concept & Original Design by Nel at 3DPrinterpunk.
Parts listed as 'Untested' may require minor modifications. This is a work in progress! I welcome your feedback but please take the following in to account:
a) parts listed as 'untested' have successfully printed, but not been used on a production printer
b) parts not labeled 'untested' have been printed, installed and tested on a production printer.
c) parts listed as FINAL have been printed, tested on a production printer and symmetry or aesthetic issues have been addressed. <2015-01-12> Modified Z-Axis Motor Mount to allow for more adjustment to reduce binding. Top Vertex marked final. <2015-01-16> reposted Z-Axis Motor Mount.
All rods are 8MM (or 5/16") , All Bearings are 608ZZ http://kitbom.com/jmwalsh/mendel-zx2-hardware-only-no-printed-parts

title: Fermentation Cap for Ball Canning Jars

description.text: Am looking at different food/cooking alternatives to improve health. As such, one of the local live/raw food places held a class last week about fermenting vegetables, and mentioned that canning jars might be ideal for small batches to try things out, hence this thing was created.. As an example of fermentation, look at a random book on amazon about it (http://www.amazon.com/Wild-Fermentation-Flavor-Nutrition-Live-Culture/dp/1931498237/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1288841311&sr=8-1). When fermenting, it releases carbon dioxide, and the goal of this thing is to keep regular air from getting at the food. If air does get at it, the food can, and most likely will, spoil and be not so good to eat. This cap is designed to fit over one of the old style Ball Canning Jars, the ones with the glass top and wire holding it on. Tried to make it somewhat easy to parameterize... hopefully.... Have not tried fermenting food using this yet, most likely soon. Am not too concerned about using ABS for this, as it won\'t come in contact with food. If you are concerned, use a different type of plastic, or something from the frostruder. Have printed this out and prints fine on my bot, but the handle isn\'t according to the stl file, but it works. Make sure to adjust your settings to print this water/air tight (at least the walls and the bottom). The idea is to fill the middle part with water, put food in jar, put top on, and put cap on top of that to seal everything in, then wait couple weeks. Might have to put something in the gap (like weatherstripping material) to fully seal the plastic top with the glass jar. It is recommended to use a finely tuned printer... Feel free to use and modify this as you want. No clue on the licensing so tried to pick an open one... And thank you again to Catarina Mota for her shapes.scad file (included)! NOTE: In the picture with the brownish liquid, that is actually apple cider I used to provide some contrast, so don't get the wrong idea.. :)

Print out a top and bottom piece
Optional, but recommended, put weatherstripping, or some type of sealant, in the bottom piece where it slides over jar to prevent air invading there Put stuff in jar to ferment (use your imagination), and put contraption on top. Fill with water so it comes below top of the breathing tube when the cap is placed in. Let sit till fermented.. Reminder to make sure it\'s water tight, at least the bottom and sides...

title: slim lm10uu Micro extruder X carraige

description.text:
UPDATE 4/23/13: Added Version 2.5 it includes addition wire clearance and some clean up for eaiser printing.
enjoy! V2.5 is for LM10UU bearings only. I wanted to maximize use of my x axis here is my solution. I am running a version from earlier in the design process this one is improved to use less plastic,minize cooling stress on ABS and to fix a problem with the fan
mounting.
I plan to print this one as soon as i have some time!.. this is printed vertically so its super strong. listing as a work in progress untill i have printed this iteration or some one else reports that it works. the side fan mount is super adjustable in an attempt to utilize it on several different carriages and get a good fit with what ever shroud you are using. the picture is the earlier version i am running now.
UPDATE 2/6/13 ADDED version 3 for use with bronze bushings that have a outside diameter of 16mm. if you need a different out side diameter just tell me ill put more up Things to do: make a lm8uu version. Add 15.9 16.1 and 16.2 versions to account for for printer Cal varaitions. Use my test bushings to figure out if the 16mm version will work for you!

you need 1 body (break out the support material between the belt clamps.
2 lower belt clamps
2 upper belt clamps
1 belt pusher.
optionally there is a side mount fan that fits across the belt clamps
there is also a shroud that contures to the inside of the carriage for a 40mm side mounted fan.
I had to shave my fan down a bit to fit between the 10 mm rails. the shroud will mount on either side or if you want supper cooling you may use two. and still use the belt clamp fan mount for cooling your print.
i use this fan shroud http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29985

comments.text: I will add it to my list of mods may take a bit its a long list but I'll get to it! Btw i highly recommend 10mm rods I went from 8 mm drill rod to hardened 10 mm they are a million times better

Bases compatible with LEGO, Mega Bloks, and other similar construction toys. 24mm x 24mm size is suitable for Dungeons and Dragons or similar games with a 1" grid pattern. You could even build your own chess set with minifigs.The 48x48mm 6x6 stud base is suitable for large creatures. You probably have some of these on hand already, but just in case you need it, here's a spare. Dec. 13 2013: My LEGO Cuusoo project was cancelled due to their new changes to their TOS, and my piece submission was no longer elegible for their program. Their loss, your gain. File updated 01/06/15. Added 20mm square, 25mm square, 25mm round, and 25x50mm cavalry bases specifically for wargaming. If you are planning to use LEGO minifigs for Kings of War, you can print complete movement trays here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:577296 and you can download the free rules here: http://www.manticgames.com/free-rules.html
Due to LEGO dimensions, either 0.1mm or 0.2mm layer height will work best. The base is 3.2mm tall, and the studs are 1.8mm tall. Choose your print settings as you see fit with this in mind.
